title: Genes of Gallgoidil: Migration of Irish,Hiberno-Norse and other Gaelic-speaking populations in the Viking Age
abstractText: Abstracts are not currently available in GtR for all funded research. This is normally because the abstract was not required at the time of proposal submission, but may be because it included sensitive information such as personal details.
findingsText:
Genetics is now a very popular part of exploring the past, but people tend to forget that it only reflects the survivors in the modern population. Our network challenged a range of assumptions: that Viking populations were small and local. We looked at 'ethnic' versus 'cultural' identities and of the key outcome is that we build a network of researchers across the Irish sea which is still active. Dr Swift gained follow-up funding from the Irish Research council for a study of surnames and DNA in Limerick, where we had included the local museum. Members of the team have become part of a large grant on 'Routs the British' at Leicester.

Another outcome is a new MA module on the Irish Sea region which is now offered at the University of Nottingham ('Virtual Viking') and which continues to include partners in Ireland, thus extending the life span of the project to a new generation. Most important is out public webpage which continues to grow.

This has been used by schools, interested member of the public and has spawned a range of public papers in both England and Ireland. Education
